trans-unit.source: Author Logic App definitions
trans-unit.target: Author Logic App definitions

trans-unit.source: Learn how to write the JSON definition for Logic apps.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to write the JSON definition for Logic apps.

trans-unit.source: Author Logic App definitions
trans-unit.target: Author Logic App definitions

trans-unit.source: This topic demonstrates how to use <link><linkText>App Services Logic Apps</linkText><title></title></link> definitions, which is a simple, declarative JSON language.
trans-unit.target: This topic demonstrates how to use <link><linkText>App Services Logic Apps</linkText><title></title></link> definitions, which is a simple, declarative JSON language.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't done so yet, check out <link><linkText>how to Create a new Logic app</linkText><title></title></link> first.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't done so yet, check out <link><linkText>how to Create a new Logic app</linkText><title></title></link> first.

trans-unit.source: You can also read the <link><linkText>full reference material of the definition language on MSDN</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can also read the <link><linkText>full reference material of the definition language on MSDN</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Several steps that repeat over a list
trans-unit.target: Several steps that repeat over a list

trans-unit.source: A common pattern is to have one step that gets a list of items, and then you have a series of two or more actions that you want to do on the list.
trans-unit.target: A common pattern is to have one step that gets a list of items, and then you have a series of two or more actions that you want to do on the list.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Repeat over lists</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Repeat over lists</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this example there are 3 actions:
trans-unit.target: In this example there are 3 actions:

trans-unit.source: Get a list of articles.
trans-unit.target: Get a list of articles.

trans-unit.source: This returns back an object that contains an array.
trans-unit.target: This returns back an object that contains an array.

trans-unit.source: An action that goes to a link property on each article, which will return back the actual location of the article.
trans-unit.target: An action that goes to a link property on each article, which will return back the actual location of the article.

trans-unit.source: An action that iterates over all of the results from the second action to download the actual articles.
trans-unit.target: An action that iterates over all of the results from the second action to download the actual articles.

trans-unit.source: As covered in use logic app features, you iterate over the first list by using the repeat: property on the second action.
trans-unit.target: As covered in use logic app features, you iterate over the first list by using the repeat: property on the second action.

trans-unit.source: However, for the third action, you need to select the @actions('readLinks').outputs.repeatItems property, because the second executed for each article.
trans-unit.target: However, for the third action, you need to select the @actions('readLinks').outputs.repeatItems property, because the second executed for each article.

trans-unit.source: Inside the action you can use either the: [repeatItem()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#repeatItem), the [repeatOutputs()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#repeatOutputs) or [repeatBody()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#repeatBody) functions.
trans-unit.target: Inside the action you can use either the: [repeatItem()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#repeatItem), the [repeatOutputs()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#repeatOutputs) or [repeatBody()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#repeatBody) functions.

trans-unit.source: In this example, I wanted to get the location header, so I used the [repeatOutputs()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#repeatOutputs) function to get the outputs of the action execution from the second action that we are now iterating over.
trans-unit.target: In this example, I wanted to get the location header, so I used the [repeatOutputs()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#repeatOutputs) function to get the outputs of the action execution from the second action that we are now iterating over.

trans-unit.source: Mapping items in a list to some different configuration
trans-unit.target: Mapping items in a list to some different configuration

trans-unit.source: Next, let's say that we want to get completely different content depending on a value of a property.
trans-unit.target: Next, let's say that we want to get completely different content depending on a value of a property.

trans-unit.source: We can create a map of values to destinations as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: We can create a map of values to destinations as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: In this case, we first get a list of articles, and then the second step looks up in a map, based on the category that was defined as a parameter, which URL to get the content from.
trans-unit.target: In this case, we first get a list of articles, and then the second step looks up in a map, based on the category that was defined as a parameter, which URL to get the content from.

trans-unit.source: Two items to pay attention here: the [intersection()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#intersection) function is used to check to see if the category matches one of the known categories defined.
trans-unit.target: Two items to pay attention here: the [intersection()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#intersection) function is used to check to see if the category matches one of the known categories defined.

trans-unit.source: Second, once we get the category, we can pull the item of the map using square brackets: parameters[...].
trans-unit.target: Second, once we get the category, we can pull the item of the map using square brackets: parameters[...].

trans-unit.source: Chain/nest Logic Apps while repeating over a list
trans-unit.target: Chain/nest Logic Apps while repeating over a list

trans-unit.source: It can often be easier to manage your Logic Apps when they are more discreet.
trans-unit.target: It can often be easier to manage your Logic Apps when they are more discreet.

trans-unit.source: You can do this by factoring your logic into multiple definitions and calling them from the same parent definition.
trans-unit.target: You can do this by factoring your logic into multiple definitions and calling them from the same parent definition.

trans-unit.source: In this example, there will be a parent Logic app that receives orders, and a child logic app that executes some steps for each order.
trans-unit.target: In this example, there will be a parent Logic app that receives orders, and a child logic app that executes some steps for each order.

trans-unit.source: In the parent logic app:
trans-unit.target: In the parent logic app:

trans-unit.source: Then, in the child logic app you'll use the [triggerBody()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#triggerBody) function to get the values that were passed into the child workflow.
trans-unit.target: Then, in the child logic app you'll use the [triggerBody()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#triggerBody) function to get the values that were passed into the child workflow.

trans-unit.source: You'll then populate the outputs with the data that you want to return to the parent flow.
trans-unit.target: You'll then populate the outputs with the data that you want to return to the parent flow.

trans-unit.source: You can read about the <link><linkText>Logic app type action on MSDN</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can read about the <link><linkText>Logic app type action on MSDN</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The Logic app designer does not support Logic app type actions so you will need to edit the definition manually.
trans-unit.target: The Logic app designer does not support Logic app type actions so you will need to edit the definition manually.

trans-unit.source: A failure-handling step if something goes wrong
trans-unit.target: A failure-handling step if something goes wrong

trans-unit.source: You commonly want to be able to write a remediation step -- some logic that executes, if , and only if, one or more of your calls failed.
trans-unit.target: You commonly want to be able to write a remediation step -- some logic that executes, if , and only if, one or more of your calls failed.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we are getting data from a variety of places, but if the call fails, I want to POST a message somewhere so I can track down that failure later.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we are getting data from a variety of places, but if the call fails, I want to POST a message somewhere so I can track down that failure later.

trans-unit.source: I am using two conditions because in the first step I am repeating over a list.
trans-unit.target: I am using two conditions because in the first step I am repeating over a list.

trans-unit.source: If you just had a single action, you'd only need one condition (the first one).
trans-unit.target: If you just had a single action, you'd only need one condition (the first one).

trans-unit.source: Also note that you can use the inputs to the failed action in your remediation step -- here I pass the failed URL to the second step.
trans-unit.target: Also note that you can use the inputs to the failed action in your remediation step -- here I pass the failed URL to the second step.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Remediation</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Remediation</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Finally, because you have now handled the error, we no longer mark the run as Failed.
trans-unit.target: Finally, because you have now handled the error, we no longer mark the run as Failed.

trans-unit.source: As you can see here, this run is Succeeded even though one step Failed, because I wrote the step to handle this failure.
trans-unit.target: As you can see here, this run is Succeeded even though one step Failed, because I wrote the step to handle this failure.

trans-unit.source: Two (or more) steps that execute in parellel
trans-unit.target: Two (or more) steps that execute in parellel

trans-unit.source: To have multiple actions execution in parellel, rather than in sequence, you need to remove the dependsOn condition that links those two actions together.
trans-unit.target: To have multiple actions execution in parellel, rather than in sequence, you need to remove the dependsOn condition that links those two actions together.

trans-unit.source: Once the dependency is removed, actions will automatically execute in parallel, unless they need data from each other.
trans-unit.target: Once the dependency is removed, actions will automatically execute in parallel, unless they need data from each other.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Branches</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Branches</linkText>

trans-unit.source: As you can see in the example above, branch1 and branch2 just depend on the content from readData.
trans-unit.target: As you can see in the example above, branch1 and branch2 just depend on the content from readData.

trans-unit.source: As a result, both of these branches will run in parallel:
trans-unit.target: As a result, both of these branches will run in parallel:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Parallel</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Parallel</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can see the timestamp for both branches is identical.
trans-unit.target: You can see the timestamp for both branches is identical.

trans-unit.source: Join two conditional branches of logic
trans-unit.target: Join two conditional branches of logic

trans-unit.source: You can combine two conditional flows of logic (that may or may not have executed) by having a single action that takes data from both branches.
trans-unit.target: You can combine two conditional flows of logic (that may or may not have executed) by having a single action that takes data from both branches.

trans-unit.source: Your strategy for this varies depending on if you are handling one item, or a collection of items.
trans-unit.target: Your strategy for this varies depending on if you are handling one item, or a collection of items.

trans-unit.source: In the case of a single item, you'll want to use the [coalesce()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#coalesce) function:
trans-unit.target: In the case of a single item, you'll want to use the [coalesce()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#coalesce) function:

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, when your first two branches both operate on a list of orders, for example, you'll want to use the [union()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#union) function to combine the data from both branches.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, when your first two branches both operate on a list of orders, for example, you'll want to use the [union()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#union) function to combine the data from both branches.

trans-unit.source: Working with Strings
trans-unit.target: Working with Strings

trans-unit.source: There are variety of functions that can be used to maniplate string.
trans-unit.target: There are variety of functions that can be used to maniplate string.

trans-unit.source: Let's take an example where we have a string that we want to pass to a system, but we are not confident that character encoding will be handled properly.
trans-unit.target: Let's take an example where we have a string that we want to pass to a system, but we are not confident that character encoding will be handled properly.

trans-unit.source: One option is to base64 encode this string.
trans-unit.target: One option is to base64 encode this string.

trans-unit.source: However, to avoid escaping in a URL we are going to replace a few characters.
trans-unit.target: However, to avoid escaping in a URL we are going to replace a few characters.

trans-unit.source: We also want a substring of the the order's name because the first 5 characters are not used.
trans-unit.target: We also want a substring of the the order's name because the first 5 characters are not used.

trans-unit.source: Working from the inside out:
trans-unit.target: Working from the inside out:

trans-unit.source: Get the [length()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#length) of the orderer's name, this returns back the total number of characters
trans-unit.target: Get the [length()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#length) of the orderer's name, this returns back the total number of characters

trans-unit.source: Subtract 5 (because we'll want a shorter string)
trans-unit.target: Subtract 5 (because we'll want a shorter string)

trans-unit.source: Actually take the [substring()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#substring) .
trans-unit.target: Actually take the [substring()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#substring) .

trans-unit.source: We start at index 5 and go the remainder of the string.
trans-unit.target: We start at index 5 and go the remainder of the string.

trans-unit.source: Convert this substring to a [base64()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#base64) string
trans-unit.target: Convert this substring to a [base64()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#base64) string

trans-unit.source: [replace()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#replace) all of the + characters with -
trans-unit.target: [replace()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#replace) all of the + characters with -

trans-unit.source: [replace()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#replace) all of the / characters with _
trans-unit.target: [replace()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#replace) all of the / characters with _

trans-unit.source: Working with Date Times
trans-unit.target: Working with Date Times

trans-unit.source: Date Times can be useful, particularly when you are trying to pull data from a data source that doesn't naturally support Triggers.
trans-unit.target: Date Times can be useful, particularly when you are trying to pull data from a data source that doesn't naturally support Triggers.

trans-unit.source: You can also use Date Times to figure out how long various steps are taking.
trans-unit.target: You can also use Date Times to figure out how long various steps are taking.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we are extracting the startTime of the previous step.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we are extracting the startTime of the previous step.

trans-unit.source: Then we are getting the current time and subtracting one second :[addseconds(..., -1)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#addseconds) (you could use other units of time such as minutes or hours).
trans-unit.target: Then we are getting the current time and subtracting one second :[addseconds(..., -1)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#addseconds) (you could use other units of time such as minutes or hours).

trans-unit.source: Finally, we can compare these two values.
trans-unit.target: Finally, we can compare these two values.

trans-unit.source: If the first is less than the second, then that means more than one second has elapsed since the order was first placed.
trans-unit.target: If the first is less than the second, then that means more than one second has elapsed since the order was first placed.

trans-unit.source: Also note that we can use string formatters to format dates: in the query string I use [utcnow('r')](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#utcnow) to get the RFC1123.
trans-unit.target: Also note that we can use string formatters to format dates: in the query string I use [utcnow('r')](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#utcnow) to get the RFC1123.

trans-unit.source: All date formatting <link><linkText>is documented on MSDN</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: All date formatting <link><linkText>is documented on MSDN</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Passing in values at runtime to vary behavior
trans-unit.target: Passing in values at runtime to vary behavior

trans-unit.source: Let's say you have different behaviors that you want to run based on some value that you use to kick off your Logic app.
trans-unit.target: Let's say you have different behaviors that you want to run based on some value that you use to kick off your Logic app.

trans-unit.source: You can use the [triggerOutputs()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#triggerOutputs) function to get these values out of what you passed in:
trans-unit.target: You can use the [triggerOutputs()](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn948512.aspx#triggerOutputs) function to get these values out of what you passed in:

trans-unit.source: To actually make this work, when you start the run you need to pass the properties you want (in the above example uriToGet and doMoreLogic).
trans-unit.target: To actually make this work, when you start the run you need to pass the properties you want (in the above example uriToGet and doMoreLogic).

trans-unit.source: Here is the call you can <link><linkText>use Basic auth for</linkText><title></title></link>:
trans-unit.target: Here is the call you can <link><linkText>use Basic auth for</linkText><title></title></link>:

trans-unit.source: With the following payload.
trans-unit.target: With the following payload.

trans-unit.source: Note that you have provided the Logic app with the values to use now:
trans-unit.target: Note that you have provided the Logic app with the values to use now:

trans-unit.source: When this logic app runs it will call the uri I passed in, and run that additional step because I passed true.
trans-unit.target: When this logic app runs it will call the uri I passed in, and run that additional step because I passed true.

trans-unit.source: If you want to only vary parameters at deployment time (not for each run), then you should use parameters as called out below.
trans-unit.target: If you want to only vary parameters at deployment time (not for each run), then you should use parameters as called out below.

trans-unit.source: Using deployment-time parameters for different environments
trans-unit.target: Using deployment-time parameters for different environments

trans-unit.source: It is common to have a deployment lifecycle where you have a development environment, a staging environment, and then a production environment.
trans-unit.target: It is common to have a deployment lifecycle where you have a development environment, a staging environment, and then a production environment.

trans-unit.source: In all of these you may want the same definition, but use different databases, for example.
trans-unit.target: In all of these you may want the same definition, but use different databases, for example.

trans-unit.source: Likewise, you may want to use the same definition across many different regions for high availability, but want each Logic app instance to talk to that region's database.
trans-unit.target: Likewise, you may want to use the same definition across many different regions for high availability, but want each Logic app instance to talk to that region's database.

trans-unit.source: Note that this is different from taking different parameters at runtime, for that you should use the trigger() function as called out above.
trans-unit.target: Note that this is different from taking different parameters at runtime, for that you should use the trigger() function as called out above.

trans-unit.source: You can start with a very simplistic definition like this one:
trans-unit.target: You can start with a very simplistic definition like this one:

trans-unit.source: Then, in the actual PUT request for the Logic app you can provide the parameter connection.
trans-unit.target: Then, in the actual PUT request for the Logic app you can provide the parameter connection.

trans-unit.source: Note, as there is no longer a default value this parameter is required in the Logic app payload:
trans-unit.target: Note, as there is no longer a default value this parameter is required in the Logic app payload:

trans-unit.source: In each environment you can then provide a different value for the connection parameter.
trans-unit.target: In each environment you can then provide a different value for the connection parameter.

trans-unit.source: See the <link><linkText>REST API documentation</linkText><title></title></link> for all of the options you have for creating and managing Logic apps.
trans-unit.target: See the <link><linkText>REST API documentation</linkText><title></title></link> for all of the options you have for creating and managing Logic apps.
